data.title: Fix the bricks
data.text: I was there for a bit as part of a greater family visit.  It's nice that Saginaw Street in downtown Flint is rebounding after decades of depression.  It honestly never looked better, and I wish I had more time to check out the new business -- I only managed to do Halo Burger since my lady wanted it.  However, I'm giving it a poor rating because the road itself needs to be fixed.  I like the bricks, but they are extremely rough - rougher than even some of the dirt roads (or paved ones) in the area.

data.title: The Bricks are the heart of Flint
data.text:
What have these bricks seen? Storefronts have changed, and activity has changed, but downtown is still vibrant.

For a few years, crime ruled these streets. Now, with the return of business and people, and with the immense help of UM-Flint, downtown has come back. 

These streets once again have life, and it appears this time it's to stay.

data.title: Great Venue ~ for the Classic Car Show or the CRIM
data.text: Flint has really been putting time, effort and money into Saginaw Street. The Main Street looks wonderful whether there to attend Back to the Bricks or to be a part of the CRIM Festival of Races. The classic cars stand out on the classic bricks that line Saginaw Street. When participating in the CRIM Festival of Races, there is nothing more thrilling than making the final turn onto Saginaw Street and completing the final leg of the race on the historic bricks. The Vehicle City arches are a nice touch to take this stretch of road back to the way it looked at the turn of the last century. Keep up the good work Flint.

data.title: A Revitalized City Center
data.text: Flint has done a really good job in revitalizing their downtown.  Several buildings have beautiful architecture and they have worked hard to protect those buildings.  There are now several restaurants, bars, and shops.  Worthwhile for you to visit if you are in Flint.

data.title: Great car show
data.text:
When the classic cars come to Downtown Flint, it is a sight too see. The old cars that are historical, still driveable, and all the difference types of cars. Come and see for yourself and you can get a first hand experience. 

The owners of the cars take well care of them, have the passion to take on a task such as, rebuilding the cars from the ground up, all new parts that are related to when the car was built. 

Come one come all to the Flint Car Show!

data.title: Beautiful
data.text: People are working very hard to revitalize downtown.  Several excellant restaurants.  The Friday night art walks are fun.  Only problem is the brick work close to the river is very rough.

data.title: Flint is a great place to hang out!
data.text: Contrary to the negative statements people say about Flint, it is a great place to gather with friends. Be it starting out with a great burger at The Torch, then heading over to The Cork for a glass of wine. Any ending up at Churchill's! Always something to do in Flint.

data.title: Neat to see
data.text: We were here on Sunday so not much open, but very picturesque & the old architecture is well worth the trip alone

data.title: Back to the Bricks
data.text: Sorry you missed 2014's BTTB, but it will be back next year, so save it on your calendar! There were many classic pre-WWII cars, as well as 50's 60's 70's and newer, including over 400 Corvettes, and 200 Mustangs and Camaros. This show is for anyone who loves all things CAR, there are dragsters and gassers, Script A's and Rat Rods, Customs and Low-Riders! Wear good walking shoes because there is over 5 miles of cars parked along Saginaw Rd and the cross streets. There are plenty of food vendors as well as many good restaurants to serve your every need. Plan on a 4 to 6 hour stay just to look at the cars and lunch.

data.title: Back To The Bricks, When Everyone Is Proud Of Flint
data.text: With the exodus of people from Flint when most of the auto manufactures moved out, there is not a lot to recommend Flint, Michigan which was once one of the most progressive cities in America. There is one time of the year when the "Old Flint" resurrects itself, Back To The Bricks is that time. Strangers smile and visit with one another, people grill on their front yards and in empty lots as vintage cars stream along Saginaw Street from Grand Blanc to Flint. There is fun  for everyone, drive along with the vintage cars, park and watch the cars go by, or join the fun walking along Saginaw Street, music and fun is everywhere.

data.title: Wonderful historic row
data.text: There are many sites to visit on this one street and it is beautiful walk. We parked at and started with the planetarium and worked our way down the street. We only had a half a day to site see since we had three days and two were for driving the other half for graduation. This made it easy to see some of MI. I know there is much more, but this was great for our limited stay!

data.title: Symbol of Motor City
data.text: The Back to the Brick is one of the best event in Flint. It is a biggest get together for all Car lover. All kind of car and bike gathered, magic show, concert. Overall it is a popular event on Saginaw St. Down town MI. Cars are just a way of bringing us together.

data.title: Lots of restaurants and bars to enjoy
data.text:
Downtown Flint still has the original brick street from decades ago.  Several blocks are adorned with lit arches featuring flags. U of M-Flint has dorms at the end of downtown and there is always activity from the Crim Festival of Races to the Back to Bricks Car Show.  You can visit restaurants and bars such as Churchill’s ( English Pub), Brown Sugar Café ( coffee and much more)  The Lunch Studio ( homemade food served in a comfortable, cozy place)  Rolls are Ready ( the best buns in town) 501 ( Upscale but unpretentious), Wize Guys ( pizzas and huge salads made to order) The Loft (small laid back bar with very low prices), Blackstones (Irish pub), Table and Tap ( the newest addition features beer and BBQ), The Flint Crepe Company ( fresh locally grown food used to make unique crepes), The Cork on Saginaw ( wine bar with food from one of the city’s best chefs), The Torch Bar and Grill ( best burgers in town), Masonic Temple Dining Room ( Homemade lunches and a Sunday All you can eat Chicken dinner) and El Potrero (fresh inexpensive Mexican food).  Hope I didn’t forget any!!

The Greater Flint Art Council also features a reception and art walk on the second Friday of each month.

data.title: Always be aware of your surroundings
data.text:
Though Flint is working on improving their image, there is a reason while we've earned the title of most violent city in America. There are many MAJOR events on Saginaw Street and as long as you travel in a group in the DAYtime, you should be okay. 

The arches and red brick streets, along with some amazing architecture, allows your imagination to wander back to yesteryear.

Paul's Pipe Shop is a MUST SEE. Back in the day actors, musicians and politicians would come from all over the world to visit with Paul. Lots of pictures to prove it in the "museum".

data.title: Car Cruse Capitol of the USA !
data.text: Being born and raised in Flint, I have seen many changes in the downtown area. From a wonderful clasic downtown of the 50`s to a crime ridden area that was dangerous ! But with the new Downtown Authority it has become a wonderful place to remember the "Hayday" of automotive history. A MUST SEE for ALL Clasic Car Lovers. Put the "Back to the Bricks" Car Cruse on your Bucket list !!

data.title: Great restaurants and historical architecture!
data.text: It's great to see the development on Saginaw Street, and businesses coming to life there! There are several excellent restaurants, including 501, Blackstone's and Cork, as well as the historical Halo Burger. The arches over Saginaw Street, based on the ones that were there in the early 20th century, create a historical ambiance, and there are a number of well preserved historical buildings with great architecture, including the Mott Foundation Building, the Capital Theatre, the Patterson Building, and the Halo Burger restaurant. There are two distinctive murals downtown also- the Vernor's mural on the side of what is now the Greater Flint Arts Council building next to Halo Burgers, and the "Overflow Parking" mural on the side of the old Flint Journal building. There is a lot to see on a walking tour of Saginaw Street and downtown, lots of parking, and some great restaurants to eat at when you need to take a break!

data.title: The best part of town
data.text: Historic Saginaw Street is updated and clean.  There are many places to shop and many events scheduled in this area.

data.title: improving
data.text: form the most violent city in america saginaw street is trying its best with new business and is clean. they still cant make up there mind on parking

data.title: Brick Main Street
data.text: Brick main street under the steel arches Flint in the old time style.

data.title: stroll through the grand history that belongs to Flint
data.text: There is a far richer history still standing in Flint than most residents are aware of.  and in the surrounding area are many resturaunts and shops that you may find very interesting.
